title: Pitch: Wrapper that adds human-mode rendering to any environment with rgb_array-rendering
body:
This PR is supposed to provide a wrapper that adds human-rendering functionality to environments that only support rgb_array rendering out of the box

---
### Pitch
Oftentimes I have found myself in a situation where I had implemented an environment that could produce RGB images, but that could not actually render the environment in real-time. It would be convenient to have a wrapper that adds this functionality. It's not that hard to add this feature yourself, but if you don't use PyGame for rendering in the first place, it may be *a lot* of boilerplate code.

---

If someone thinks that this might be a good idea, I will start adding documentation and tests if necessary. Not sure whether I'm missing something, but this seems like a wrapper that could be quite useful (at least I will be using it personally).

title: Pytest warnings to errors
body:
As I noted in #2602, it would be nice if the pytest warnings were thrown as errors so if new changes caused issues
Building upon #2602 that updated the CI and #2703 that fixed warnings (but hasn't been PR yet) 

This fixes all warnings from #2660, mostly through added filterwarnings to prevent the warnings from being thrown

title: Render API
body:
## New render API
Following this discussion: #2540

This PR changes eliminates the `render()` method in favor of `collect_render()`.
The `render_mode` is specified during the instantiation of the environment; the environment handles internally the rendering.
In case `render_mode = "human"`, the method `collect_render()` return `self.isopen` if there the environment use some resources that should be closed or simply `None`.
With other render modes, `collect_render()` returns a proper `List` with all the renders from the last `reset()`. For example, with `render_mode = "rgb_array"`, `collect_render()` returns a `List` of `np.ndarray`, while with `render_mode = "ansi"` a `List[str]`.

## Example

```
import gym

env = gym.make('FrozenLake-v1')  # default: render_mode="human"
env.reset()
for _ in range(100):
    env.step(env.action_space.sample())
    
env.collect_render()
> None
```

```
import gym

env = gym.make('CartPole-v1', render_mode="rgb_array")
env.reset()

for _ in range(10):
    env.step(env.action_space.sample())

type(env.collect_render())
> <class 'list'>
len(env.collect_render())
> 11

env.reset()
len(env.collect_render())
> 1
```

title: Add SpaceWrapper, FilteredSpace and Space.where
body:
This PR adds a new feature that makes the gym spaces a lot more expressive: **Filtered** spaces!

There are 3 components in this PR:
- `SpaceWrapper` (in `gym/spaces/other/wrapper.py`):
    - Same idea as `gym.Wrapper`, but for spaces! This can serve as the basis for a bunch of cool adapters for gym spaces in the future! For example, something like a `TensorSpaceWrapper`, that converts the samples to/from Tensors in the `sample` and `contains`, respectively.
- `FilteredSpace`  (in `gym/spaces/other/filter.py`):
    - Adds assumptions (predicates) to a space, limiting the samples that are considered valid.
    - Uses rejection sampling with a maximum of `max_sampling_attempts` attempts.
- `Space.where(predicate)`:
    - Adds filters to the space, returning a `SpaceWrapper`.


```python
>>> from gym.spaces import Discrete, Box, Space
>>> import numpy as np

>>> odd_digits = Discrete(10, seed=123).where(lambda n: n % 2 == 1)
>>> 1 in odd_digits
True
>>> 2 in odd_digits
False
>>> odd_digits.sample()
5
```
Other cool examples:
```python
>>> unit_circle = Box(-1, 1, shape=(2,), dtype=np.float64, seed=123).where(lambda xy: (xy ** 2).sum() <= 1)
>>> np.array((0.1, 0.2)) in unit_circle
True
>>> np.array((1, 1)) in unit_circle
False
>>> unit_circle.sample()
array([ 0.36470373, -0.89235796])

>>> def hypersphere(radius: float, dimensions: int) -> FilteredSpace[np.ndarray]:
...     return Box(-radius, +radius, shape=(dimensions,)).where(
...         lambda v: v.pow(2).sum() <= radius**dimensions
...     )
...
>>> unit_sphere = hypersphere(radius=1, dimensions=3)
```

title: Bugfix: Allow Nesting of Sync/Async VectorEnvs
body:
Allows for the nesting of Async/Sync VectorEnvs

- 2-level nesting of any combination of SyncVectorEnv/AsyncVectorEnv  (i.e. Sync/Sync, Sync/Async, Async/Sync, Async/Async*)
 - Tested with the "CubeCrash-v0" and "CartPole-v0" environments

*: When nesting Async/Async environments, only the innermost env can have `daemon=True`, since daemonic processes cannot have children.

Somewhat related to #2072 (based on a suggestion from @tristandeleu ). A new Wrapper could also be eventually be introduced in another PR to "unchunk" the observations/actions/rewards/dones, (flatten the first two batch dimensions).

There currently aren't any tests specifically about the handling of Tuple/Dict/non-standard observation/action spaces. I could add some, if those cases aren't already covered by `test_[sync/async]_vector_env.py`.


Signed-off-by: Fabrice Normandin <fabrice.normandin@gmail.com>

title: [gym.vector] Add BatchedVectorEnv, (chunking + flexible n_envs)
body:
Adds the following features, compared to using the vectorized Async and Sync
VectorEnvs:

-   Chunking: Running more than one environment per worker. This is done by
    passing `SyncVectorEnv`s as the env_fns to the `AsyncVectorEnv`.

-   Flexible batch size: Supports any number of environments, irrespective
    of the number of workers or of CPUs. The number of environments will be
    spread out as equally as possible between the workers.

    For example, if you want to have a batch_size of 17, and n_workers is 6,
    then the number of environments per worker will be: [3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 2].

    Internally, this works by creating up to two AsyncVectorEnvs, env_a and
    env_b. If the number of envs (batch_size) isn't a multiple of the number
    of workers, then we create the second AsyncVectorEnv (env_b).

    In the first environment (env_a), each env will contain
    ceil(n_envs / n_workers) each. If env_b is needed, then each of its envs
    will contain floor(n_envs / n_workers) environments.

    The observations/actions/rewards are reshaped to be (n_envs, *shape), i.e.
    they don't have an extra 'chunk' dimension.


Signed-off-by: Fabrice Normandin <fabrice.normandin@gmail.com>

repo.name: gym
repo.description: A toolkit for developing and comparing reinforcement learning algorithms.
